title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: There is no difficulty infinding a house numbered 200, as you will find it between the secondand third street, and so on. The streets from left to right of ChestnutStreet run in rhyme (Chestnut, Walnut, Spruce, and Pine; Market,Arch, Race, and Vine, being on the left), Chestnut Street being theprincipal one, the finest hotels and shops are to be found in it,although it is only fifty feet wide. Broad Street is one hundred andthirteen feet wide, Market Street one hundred feet, all the others fromfifty to sixty-six feet wide.

title: A Holiday Tour in Europe. Described in a series of letters written for The Public Ledger, etc
author: Cook, Joel.
snippet: It wasfrom these great Parisian bazaars that Mr. Wanamaker got thedesign of his, and the extent of these, especially of the " BonMarche," is something astonishing, covering a large surface. But with its many thousands of shops, and its rows of showwindows, and its miles of magnificent streets devoted to businesspurposes, there does not exist in Paris anything in the wayof show-window displays that equals the scene on ChestnutStreet, from the Ledger Building for a mile west beyondBroad Street. There are at least a hundred show-windows
